abstract.p: Letter by economist Judy Shelton disputes Paul Krugman's June 4 column defending government-knows-best policies of Keynes (S)

block.p: It was flattering to recognize my words in Paul Krugman's June 4 column about economic ideologies. But he cites my defense of sound money to highlight his opposite view that governments should print money to stimulate a depressed economy.

The debate over whether a free-market approach has better economic outcomes than central planning has been resolved. When Mr. Krugman defends the government-knows-best policies of John Maynard Keynes, he shows a disdain for capitalism and the individual's ability to make rational economic decisions.

Entrepreneurs need money that is a meaningful unit of account and a reliable store of value. Currency devaluation is not only economically self-defeating; it's immoral.
The gold standard has many admirers -- including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman -- because it represents discipline, not political expediency.
